questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He had difficulty chewing his food at breakfast. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. He is in no apparent distress. His vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance
Corticosteroid therapy
Surgical repair
Acyclovir therapy
Surgical decompression

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient presents with delayed facial nerve palsy following trauma. Given the underlying traumatic etiology and the fact that he is symptomatic, reassurance alone is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Peripheral facial nerve palsy following facial trauma is caused by temporal bone fracture or trauma. Management typically depends on symptom onset. Acute onset of symptoms following facial trauma is usually caused by nerve injury (e.g., transection); therefore, surgery (e.g., nerve repair) may be indicated. A delayed presentation (e.g., one day after trauma) is most likely secondary to edema within the facial nerve canal. In this patient, corticosteroid therapy is indicated to control swelling within the facial nerve canal. If this patient's facial nerve palsy does not improve or worsens, surgical decompression of the facial nerve canal is indicated.

Proper eye care with artificial tears and moisturizing ointments is an important part of managing lagophthalmos.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary nerve repair with good nerve approximation may reduce the degree of facial paralysis, and would be the appropriate step in management if there was direct transection of the facial nerve. However, the patient presented with delayed facial nerve palsy (one day after the traumatic event), which indicates that nerve transection is not the underlying pathology in this patient. Moreover, the CT scan does not show evidence of a transverse fracture of the temporal bone nor is there a penetrating injury near the cheek to suggest facial nerve transection.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy is appropriate for Bell palsy or facial palsy from a viral infection (e.g., herpes zoster). Although the patient presents with clinical features associated with Bell palsy (e.g. lagophthalmos, flattened nasolabial fold, drooping of a corner of the mouth), his facial palsy is likely the result of his recent trauma. In addition, the patient does not report dermatomal pain or vesicles near the external meatus, which would be expected in herpes zoster.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with delayed facial nerve palsy following traumatic injury, surgical decompression is only indicated if the presenting symptoms do not improve or continue to worsen with first-line therapy (short course of high-dose steroids). Surgical decompression of the facial nerve puts the patient at risk for further injury to an already injured nerve, may prolong or prevent nerve recovery, and carries the risk of additional complications such as hearing loss, vestibular function loss, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, and meningitis.
questions.hint: Facial muscle paralysis (lagophthalmos of the left eye, drooping of the left corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an increasing right-sided cheek swelling for 2 years. He has had recurrent right-sided oral ulcers for the past 2 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a beer every night. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/83 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the right jaw. There is no overlying erythema or induration. There are multiple shallow ulcers on the right buccal mucosa and mandibular marginal gingiva. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a soft tissue mass in the parotid gland. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A right-sided total parotidectomy is scheduled. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following early complications?

choices.text: Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe
Hyperacusis of the right ear
Xerostomia when eating
Paralysis of the right lower lip
Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
Flushing and sweating of the right cheek while eating

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sensation of the ear lobe is provided by the greater auricular nerve. Hypoesthesia, not hyperesthesia, of the greater auricular nerve is a common complication of parotidectomy due to nerve transection during surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperacusis can be a symptom of facial nerve dysfunction (e.g., Bell palsy) due to consequent weakness of the stapedius muscle. The nerve to the stapedius branches off from the facial nerve before the facial nerve exits the skull, which means that stapedius dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

The parotid gland produces ∼ 40% of the saliva and is stimulated by eating. The total amount of saliva is therefore likely to be slightly decreased after parotidectomy. However, given the continued production of saliva from the remaining salivary glands, xerostomia is not a common complication of the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

Facial nerve palsy is the most common early complication of parotidectomy, and the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve, which provides motor control of the lower lip, is one of the most commonly injured branches of the facial nerve. Most cases of post-parotidectomy facial nerve palsy resolve within one month.

Because parotid adenoid cystic carcinomas of the parotid gland grow along nerve sheaths, the facial nerve cannot always be preserved during parotidectomy.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Taste and sensation in the posterior third of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Glossopharyngeal nerve damage is not a complication of parotidectomy.

The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve is responsible for taste of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it joins the facial nerve inside the facial canal (thus inside the skull), which means that chorda tympani dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

F) INCORRECT:

Flushing and sweating of the cheek while eating is characteristic of Frey syndrome, which is a common complication of parotidectomy that results in surgical injury of parasympathetic nerve fibers. However, Frey syndrome manifests late (up to one year after surgery) because of the slow regeneration of the affected parasympathetic fibers and is thus unlikely to cause symptoms earlier than one month after surgery.
questions.hint: The facial nerve runs through the parotid gland and is most likely to be damaged during a total parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of disorientation and slurred speech. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His blood pressure is 210/110 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. Once the patient is stabilized, an MRI of the brain is performed, which shows an infarct of the left precentral gyrus involving the region that supplies the facial nerve. Given the MRI findings, which of the following neurological findings would most be expected?

choices.text: Loss of taste in the posterior third of the right half of the tongue
Flattening of the right nasolabial fold
Decreased lacrimation of the left eye
Drooping of the left eyelid
Hyperacusis of the left ear
Inability to raise the right eyebrow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taste to the posterior third of the tongue is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve and would therefore not be impaired in central facial nerve palsy. Facial nerve palsy may affect taste sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, since this region is innervated by the parasympathetic fibers supplied by the chorda tympani. However, central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral deficits, and a lesion to the precentral gyrus, the location of the primary motor cortex, does not affect taste.

B) CORRECT:

Flattening of the right nasolabial fold would be expected in central facial nerve palsy. The facial motor nucleus has two regions: one that supplies the muscles of the forehead and a second that supplies the rest of the face. The branches of the facial nerve that innervate the forehead are activated by both cerebral hemispheres, whereas the branches innervating the lower portion of the face are only activated by the contralateral cerebral hemisphere. As a result, the forehead is spared with unilateral infarction of the precentral gyrus, while the contralateral lower face becomes paralyzed.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Lacrimation of the eye is modulated by the greater petrosal nerve, a branch of the facial nerve that carries parasympathetic fibers, and could therefore be impaired by peripheral facial nerve palsy. Decreased lacrimation of the left eye would be expected in left-sided peripheral facial palsy. However, central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral deficits, and a lesion to the precentral gyrus, the location of the primary motor cortex, does not affect lacrimation.

D) INCORRECT:

Drooping of the ipsilateral eyelid is seen in third nerve palsy, which may be caused by trauma, ischemia, migraine (cranial neuralgia), intracranial aneurysm or is idiopathic (Bell palsy). In central facial nerve palsy, drooping of the eyelid would not be expected, since the forehead is innervated by fibers from both cerebral hemispheres.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperacusis of the left ear would be a result of paralysis of the stapedius muscle. The stapedius muscle is supplied by the nerve to stapedius, a branch of the facial nerve, and could therefore be impaired in facial nerve palsy. Hyperacusis of the left ear would be expected in left-sided peripheral facial palsy. However, since central facial nerve palsy causes contralateral lesions, in this patient hyperacusis of the right ear would be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Inability to raise the right eyebrow is seen in ipsilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, which is commonly caused by trauma (e.g., zygomatic fractures, lacerations), infection (e.g., herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus), tumors (e.g., neuromas, parotid gland tumors), or is idiopathic (Bell palsy). In central facial nerve palsy, drooping of the eyebrow would not be expected, since the forehead is innervated by fibers from both cerebral hemispheres.
questions.hint: A lesion of the corticobulbar tract between the precentral gyrus and the brainstem nuclei of the facial nerve causes central facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing swelling in his left cheek and recurrent oral ulcers for 1 year. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the left jaw. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A left-sided total parotidectomy is performed. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Hyperesthesia of the left ear lobe
Impaired taste of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
Flushing of the right cheek while eating
Inability to wrinkle the left side of the forehead
Hyperacusis of the left ear

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sensation of the earlobe is provided by the greater auricular nerve. Hypoesthesia, not hyperesthesia, of the skin innervated by the greater auricular nerve is a common complication of parotidectomy due to nerve transection during surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Taste and sensation in the posterior third of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve, which does not run near the parotid gland but more dorsally, between the internal jugular vein and the internal carotid artery. Glossopharyngeal nerve damage is, therefore, not an expected complication of parotidectomy.

The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve is responsible for transmitting taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it joins the facial nerve inside the facial canal (thus inside the skull), which means that chorda tympani dysfunction is not a potential complication of parotidectomy.
Image Description:

The first neuron of the taste pathway is located in the ganglia of the facial, vagus, and glossopharyngeal nerves. The afferent gustatory nerve fibers join to form the nerve tract that projects to the nucleus of the solitary tract.

Second-order neurons project from the medulla oblongata in three distinct branches. Projections to the hypothalamus and amygdala transmit the emotional component of taste perception. Projections to the ventral posterior nucleus (VPM) of the thalamus transmit to the gustatory cortex at the foot of the postcentral gyrus for conscious taste perception.

C) INCORRECT:

Flushing and sweating of the cheek while eating is characteristic of Frey syndrome, which is a late complication of parotidectomy. Frey syndrome is due to inappropriate parasympathetic nerve regrowth. However, Frey syndrome affects the ipsilateral cheek and would, therefore, affect the left cheek in a patient who underwent left parotidectomy, not the right cheek.

D) CORRECT:

Unilateral inability to wrinkle the forehead is a sign of ipsilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy, the most common complication of parotidectomy. Injury to the facial nerve during parotidectomy results in an impairment of the ipsilateral muscles of facial expression, including the muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements.

Most cases of post-parotidectomy facial nerve palsy resolve within one month.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperacusis may be a symptom of facial nerve dysfunction (e.g., Bell palsy) due to associated weakness of the stapedius muscle. The nerve to the stapedius branches off of the facial nerve before the facial nerve exits the skull, which means that stapedius dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.
questions.hint: The facial nerve runs through the parotid gland and is most likely to be damaged during a procedure such as total parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of an 8-hour history of drooping of the right side of his face. His mother noticed that he also started drooling when trying to drink water. Two days ago, he complained of mild pain behind his right ear and difficulty hearing, which resolved after a few hours. Medical history is remarkable for a humerus fracture 1 year ago and chickenpox 5 years ago. He takes no medications. He lives in Texas with his parents and two siblings and has no recent history of travel. Temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an inability to fully close the right eye and drooping of the right corner of the mouth. There is decreased movement on the right side of the forehead when he is asked to elevate his eyebrows. There are no palpable masses and no lymphadenopathy of the head and neck. Hearing is intact, and external examination of the ears is unremarkable. Bilateral otoscopic examination shows intact tympanic membranes and normal light reflexes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Serum PCR test for varicella-zoster virus
MRI of the head and neck
No further evaluation is necessary
Lumbar puncture
Serologic testing for Lyme disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A serum PCR test for varicella-zoster virus can be used to confirm a diagnosis of herpes zoster oticus, which can manifest with unilateral facial nerve palsy and ear pain. However, this patient lacks the characteristic finding of herpes zoster oticus, which is the development of vesicles in the auditory canal or ear. Moreover, herpes zoster is uncommon in pediatric patients.

B) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the head and neck can be used to diagnose peripheral facial nerve palsy caused by direct compression, which is usually due to parotid or cerebellopontine angle tumors. In contrast to this patient's acute onset of symptoms, nerve palsy caused by mass effect manifests with a prolonged, slow onset of symptoms. In addition, this patient's physical examination did not show any masses. Moreover, parotid and cerebellopontine tumors are uncommon in pediatric patients.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic peripheral facial nerve palsy, also known as Bell palsy, is a clinical diagnosis that is typically made through detailed patient history and physical examination. This patient has the classic presentation of this condition, which consists of the acute onset of diffuse facial nerve involvement. Diagnostic studies are not routinely needed for acute, unilateral facial nerve palsies. Imaging studies and blood tests are appropriate for atypical presentations, such as a slowly progressive palsy (which may be caused by mass effect from a tumor) or bilateral involvement (which may be caused by Lyme disease). Individuals with risk factors for the development of facial nerve palsy (e.g., history of trauma, travel to a region in which Lyme disease is endemic) should also receive further diagnostic evaluation. Idiopathic peripheral facial nerve palsy is treated with oral glucocorticoids, which should be administered within 72 hours of disease onset to maximize the chance of full facial nerve function recovery.

D) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis can be used to diagnose facial nerve paralysis caused by central nervous system infection (e.g., meningitis) or inflammation (e.g., Guillain-Barre syndrome). CSF findings in patients with meningitis (e.g., abnormal white blood cell count and glucose) vary depending on the underlying cause (e.g., viral, bacterial). For patients with GBS, CSF analysis shows albuminocytologic dissociation. This patient does not have other typical features of meningitis (e.g., fever, prolonged headache, nuchal rigidity, altered mental status) or GBS (e.g., bilateral symmetric facial nerve palsy, ascending bilateral flaccid paralysis), so lumbar puncture is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing for Lyme disease is recommended for patients with peripheral facial nerve palsy who have recently been exposed to Borrelia burgdorferi (e.g., tick bite) or have risk factors for exposure (e.g., travel to high-risk areas like the Northeastern and Midwestern US), neither of which is the case for this patient. Furthermore, this patient lacks other symptoms typically associated with early disseminated Lyme disease, such as migratory arthralgia and erythema migrans.
questions.hint: Acute paralysis of the right facial muscles (e.g., inability to close the right eye, drooping of the right corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with right peripheral facial nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive weakness on the right side of her face. During this time, she has also noticed increased dryness of her right eye. Her medical history is remarkable for migraine headaches for which she takes sumatriptan. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years and does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. Examination shows asymmetrical facial expression with a right-sided drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is deeply concerned that her current symptoms are going to be permanent. She asks what her long-term prognosis will be. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concern?

choices.text: “I can make an accurate statement about your prognosis only after obtaining imaging studies of your head.”
”With oral prednisone therapy, approximately 2 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”
”Even without treatment, at least 7 out of 10 patients with your condition will fully recover within 1 year.”
”These symptoms are likely to be permanent, as there is currently no effective treatment for your condition.”
"These symptoms will likely resolve spontaneously within a few months, but almost 9 out of 10 patients with your condition develop facial contractures as a late complication."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Facial nerve palsy can be caused by stroke. In patients with suspected stroke, imaging of the head (e.g., CT, MRI) is an important diagnostic tool. However, the palsy in stroke is of central rather than peripheral origin. Although the conditions have similar symptoms (e.g., drooping mouth), the inability to frown and close the eyelid are not features of central facial nerve palsy. Imaging studies are not routinely performed in Bell palsy.

B) INCORRECT:

While oral glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) should be initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset to decrease inflammation and compression of the facial nerve in Bell palsy, the vast majority (≥ 80%) of patients recover completely with glucocorticoid treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Peripheral facial nerve palsy is most commonly idiopathic (i.e., Bell palsy). The diagnosis is made clinically after conducting a thorough medical history and physical examination. Bell palsy is treated with oral glucocorticoids (preferably within 72 hours of symptom onset) and most cases resolve within three weeks. Even without treatment, this condition resolves spontaneously in the majority of cases (∼ 70 %) in 3–6 months.

Because viral reactivation may be the cause of Bell palsy, antiviral therapy with acyclovir or valacyclovir should be considered in addition to oral glucocorticoids.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids decrease inflammation and compression of the facial nerve and are successfully used in the treatment of Bell palsy. The vast majority of patients recover completely with glucocorticoid treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Facial synkinesis and contractures are late complications of Bell palsy that are caused by abnormal regrowth of the facial nerve. These complications manifest as the involuntary contraction of facial muscles during voluntary contraction of other facial muscles (e.g., the involuntary elevation of the angle of the mouth during forceful blinking). However, these complications only develop in a minority of patients (approx. 15%).
questions.hint: Acute onset of progressive unilateral facial weakness, decreased lacrimation, drooping mouth, upper eyelid retraction, inability to frown, and loss of forehead wrinkling are consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents for assessment of left-sided facial weakness that he first noticed when he woke up 6 hours ago. He reports drooling from the left corner of his mouth, an inability to close his left eye, and an inability to move either the upper or lower side of the left half of his face. He has had no dysphagia, double vision, pain in his ear, or dizziness; he has been slightly more sensitive to noises. He has no significant medical history and denies any recent tick bites or any symptoms suggestive of an upper respiratory tract infection.
On physical examination, he has normal vital signs and is afebrile. His tympanic membranes and ear canals are normal in appearance, his oropharynx is without exudate, and his neck is supple. His pupils are equal and reactive to light and accommodation; his extraocular movements are normal. Facial sensation is intact in all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve. He is unable to raise his left eyebrow or completely close his left eye. The left corner of his mouth does not move when he is asked to smile. The nasolabial fold is flatter on the left than on the right. His cognition seems to be intact. The rest of the cranial nerves and neurologic examination are normal. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and his cardiac examination is regular, without murmurs. He has no rash.
In addition to taking steps to prevent corneal damage, which one of the following next steps is most likely to be beneficial in this patient?

choices.text: Noncontrast CT of the brain followed by intravenous alteplase if normal
Intravenous ceftriaxone for 10 days
Surgical decompression of the facial nerve
Oral doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 2 weeks
Oral prednisone for 10 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous ceftriaxone would be appropriate if meningitis was suspected, but this patient has a low clinical probability of this diagnosis, given the lack of fever, headaches, neck stiffness, and constitutional symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no indication for surgical decompression of the facial nerve in idiopathic facial nerve palsy, although surgery might be indicated if a tumor is present.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone and doxycycline are possible treatments for Lyme disease, which is a known cause of facial nerve palsy. Testing for Lyme disease is reasonable in patients with facial nerve palsy, especially in Lyme-endemic areas in the spring, summer, or fall, but antibiotics should not be initiated unless there is serologic confirmation of the disease or high clinical suspicion based on the presence of bilateral facial nerve palsy or other symptoms of Lyme disease, such as constitutional symptoms, rash, hearing loss, or other cranial neuropathies.

E) CORRECT:

Bell palsy (idiopathic facial nerve palsy) and stroke are the two most common causes of unilateral facial weakness. In this case, the patient has unilateral weakness of both the upper and lower face, which strongly suggests a peripheral lesion. Although the eyes and forehead receive innervation from both cerebral hemispheres, the lower face receives innervation only from the contralateral hemisphere. A single cerebral lesion would not cause weakness of the entire side of the face.

Although facial nerve palsy can be caused by infection, autoimmune disease, tumors, and other processes, it is most often idiopathic. Bell palsy is fairly common, with an annual incidence of 20 cases per 100,000 people.

Treatment for Bell palsy consists of a short course of oral glucocorticoids, which has been shown in multiple trials to increase the likelihood of complete recovery of facial function. In clinical practice, glucocorticoids are often combined with an antiviral agent (acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir) based on evidence suggesting that this combination can improve outcomes further, but the quality of the studies supporting this approach was hampered by trial design. If this patient had signs or symptoms of ear involvement or a rash consistent with Ramsay Hunt syndrome (vesicles in the auditory canal or pinna), valacyclovir treatment would be much more likely to be beneficial.

Key learning point: Glucocorticoids increase the likelihood of complete recovery of facial function in patients with Bell palsy.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department reporting drooping of the right side of his face, including his mouth and eyebrow, and difficulty closing his right eye since this morning. He also notes 2 days of right-ear pain, both on the auricle and in the ear canal, and increased sensitivity to sound in that ear.
Physical examination confirms right facial droop and an inability to close the right eye. The patient is also unable to wrinkle the right side of his forehead. A cluster of vesicles is noted at the entrance to the ear canal.
In addition to prescribing eye lubrication and patching, which one of the following treatments is best for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Otic ciprofloxacin-dexamethasone drops
Oral acyclovir and prednisone
Topical 2.5% hydrocortisone cream
Oral doxycycline
Carbamazepine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The lesions in Ramsay Hunt syndrome can occur within the ear canal, mimicking otitis externa. However, given that this patient’s symptoms and lesions are likely due to varicella-zoster virus, treatment for otitis externa, such as ciprofloxacin-dexamethasone drops, would not be indicated.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a palsy of the peripheral facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve) with a lesion on his ear consistent with Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus). He has facial weakness, including drooping of the eyebrow and mouth, difficulty closing the eye, and hyperacusis. Involvement of the forehead muscles helps to distinguish a peripheral nerve palsy from a central lesion, which would involve only the lower portion of the face and would not be associated with changes in hearing.

Peripheral facial nerve palsy is often caused by idiopathic Bell palsy, which is thought to be inflammatory in nature, often following a nonspecific viral illness. However, this patient has a vesicular eruption on the auricle, which is more consistent with Ramsay Hunt syndrome. Ramsay Hunt syndrome is characterized by acute facial palsy with a painful vesicular eruption on the auricle. It is caused by reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus in the geniculate ganglion.

Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a clinical diagnosis. Although a vesicle swab can be evaluated for varicella-zoster virus, patients with a typical history and examination do not require confirmatory testing. Treatment with an antiviral medication, such as acyclovir or valacyclovir, as well as a glucocorticoid should be initiated early to provide the best chance of recovery from facial paralysis.

Patients with peripheral facial nerve palsy are at risk for corneal abrasion related to weakness of eye closure. Therefore, eye patches, artificial tears, or ophthalmic ointment (or some combination of these) should be used to protect the eye until the patient has recovered the ability to close it.

Key learning point: Appropriate management for Ramsay Hunt syndrome includes eye lubrication, patching, and oral acyclovir or valacyclovir.

C) INCORRECT:

Poison ivy or other contact dermatitides may manifest with vesicles and can be treated with topical glucocorticoids (e.g., hydrocortisone cream) but would not be expected to induce a palsy of the seventh cranial nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is indicated for facial nerve palsy due to Lyme disease, which does not cause a vesicular eruption on the auricle. This patient's facial nerve palsy most likely has a viral cause.

E) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine can be used for pain in Ramsay Hunt syndrome but is not the first line of treatment.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of facial drooping on the left side since awakening that morning. He was treated the previous day at the hospital after sustaining a head injury from falling off of a ladder. A CT scan of the head showed no abnormalities. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is drooping on the left corner of the mouth. The left nasolabial fold is flattened. When he is asked to close both eyes, his left eye remains partially open. When he is asked to raise his eyebrows, there are no wrinkles on the left side of his forehead. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassurance
Corticosteroid therapy
Surgical repair
Acyclovir therapy
Surgical decompression

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient presents with delayed facial nerve palsy following trauma. Given the underlying traumatic etiology and the fact that he is symptomatic, reassurance alone is not indicated.

B) CORRECT:

Peripheral facial nerve palsy following facial trauma is caused by temporal bone fracture or trauma. Management typically depends on symptom onset. Acute onset of symptoms following facial trauma is usually caused by nerve injury (e.g., transection); therefore, surgery (e.g., nerve repair) may be indicated. A delayed presentation (e.g., one day after trauma) is most likely secondary to edema within the facial nerve canal. In this patient, corticosteroid therapy is indicated to control swelling within the facial nerve canal. If this patient's facial nerve palsy does not improve or worsens, surgical decompression of the facial nerve canal is indicated.

Proper eye care with artificial tears and moisturizing ointments is an important part of managing lagophthalmos.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary nerve repair with good nerve approximation may reduce the degree of facial paralysis, and would be the appropriate step in management if there was direct transection of the facial nerve. However, the patient presented with delayed facial nerve palsy (one day after the traumatic event), which indicates that nerve transection is not the underlying pathology in this patient. Moreover, the CT scan does not show evidence of a transverse fracture of the temporal bone nor is there a penetrating injury near the cheek to suggest facial nerve transection.

D) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir therapy is appropriate for Bell palsy or facial palsy from a viral infection (e.g., herpes zoster). Although the patient presents with clinical features associated with Bell palsy (e.g. lagophthalmos, flattened nasolabial fold, drooping of a corner of the mouth), his facial palsy is likely the result of his recent trauma. In addition, the patient does not report dermatomal pain or vesicles near the external meatus, which would be expected in herpes zoster.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with delayed facial nerve palsy following traumatic injury, surgical decompression is only indicated if the presenting symptoms do not improve or continue to worsen with first-line therapy (short course of high-dose steroids). Surgical decompression of the facial nerve puts the patient at risk for further injury to an already injured nerve, may prolong or prevent nerve recovery, and carries the risk of additional complications such as hearing loss, vestibular function loss, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, and meningitis.
questions.hint: Facial muscle paralysis (lagophthalmos of the left eye, drooping of the left corner of the mouth) that does not spare the ipsilateral forehead is consistent with peripheral facial nerve palsy.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with sudden onset of left-sided facial droop upon awakening. He reports difficulty closing his left eye and inability to raise his left eyebrow. Examination reveals flattening of the left nasolabial fold and no movement in the upper or lower facial muscles on the left side. He denies any rash or pain around the ear. Sensory examination of the face is intact, and no other neurological deficits are detected.
What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Acoustic neuroma
Ramsay Hunt syndrome
Bell's palsy
Ischemic stroke

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acoustic neuroma, a vestibular schwannoma, typically presents with gradual symptoms like unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance issues. The acute onset of complete unilateral facial paralysis without auditory or vestibular symptoms suggests isolated peripheral facial nerve dysfunction, not acoustic neuroma.

B) INCORRECT:

Ramsay Hunt syndrome involves unilateral facial palsy with a painful vesicular rash on the ear or auditory canal, and may include hearing loss or vertigo. The absence of rash, ear pain, or additional cranial nerve involvement in this patient argues against Ramsay Hunt syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Bell’s palsy manifests with acute, unilateral peripheral facial nerve paralysis, affecting both upper and lower facial muscles. The inability to raise the eyebrow indicates a peripheral lesion, as central lesions typically spare the forehead due to bilateral cortical innervation. This condition is often linked to inflammation and swelling of the facial nerve, possibly from viral reactivation, leading to compression and ischemia. The sudden onset of facial droop with preserved facial sensation aligns with idiopathic neuropathy of the facial nerve, characteristic of Bell’s palsy.

Key learning point: Facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) dysfunction can lead to Bell's palsy, characterized by facial muscle weakness or paralysis, inability to close the eye, and loss of forehead wrinkling on the affected side.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemic stroke often spares upper facial muscles due to bilateral cortical innervation, leading to lower facial muscle weakness. The complete facial muscle involvement, including the inability to raise the eyebrow, and absence of other neurological deficits, makes ischemic stroke unlikely.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of left-sided facial weakness. He reports difficulty closing his left eye and drooping at the corner of his mouth. He denies recent infections or trauma and reports occasional hyperacusis on the affected side. Examination shows forehead involvement, with no rash or hearing changes.
What is the most appropriate therapy to shorten the duration of his symptoms?

choices.text: Oral antivirals alone
Surgical decompression of the facial nerve
Oral corticosteroids
MRI of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral antivirals alone are not effective in Bell palsy, as the primary benefit in reducing inflammation and edema comes from corticosteroids. The absence of vesicular rash or otologic symptoms makes a viral etiology less likely, and randomized trials show no significant benefit from antivirals without steroids.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression is considered for extrinsic compression or traumatic nerve entrapment, not for idiopathic inflammatory facial nerve palsy like Bell palsy. Noninvasive management with corticosteroids is preferred, as surgery carries risks and does not shorten symptom duration.

C) CORRECT:

Bell palsy manifests as unilateral facial weakness due to idiopathic inflammation of the facial nerve, affecting both upper and lower facial muscles. Symptoms include difficulty closing the eye, mouth drooping, and hyperacusis. Oral corticosteroids, administered within 72 hours of symptom onset, reduce nerve inflammation and edema, shortening symptom duration and improving recovery. This treatment targets the inflammatory process, minimizing secondary nerve injury and promoting recovery.

Key learning point: Corticosteroid therapy is the most effective treatment to shorten the duration of symptoms in Bell palsy by reducing inflammation and edema of the facial nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is not indicated for typical Bell's palsy, which presents with sudden unilateral facial weakness involving the forehead and no other focal neurologic deficits. MRI is reserved for atypical features or suspected central causes, but it does not shorten symptom duration.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acute onset of right-sided facial weakness that began 6 hours ago. He reports difficulty drinking liquids and speaking clearly. On examination, he has right-sided mouth drooping and a flattened nasolabial fold. His speech is slightly slurred but comprehensible. He can raise both eyebrows symmetrically and close both eyes completely. The remainder of his neurological examination shows no other focal deficits. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order MRI of the brain with gadolinium
Prescribe oral prednisone and arrange outpatient follow-up
Administer tissue plasminogen activator
Obtain emergent CT angiography of the head and neck
Consult neurosurgery for urgent evaluation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The preserved ability to raise eyebrows and close eyes indicates central facial nerve palsy, suggesting a brainstem lesion. An MRI with gadolinium is the appropriate imaging modality to evaluate for brainstem stroke, demyelinating disease, or other central nervous system pathology that can cause isolated central facial palsy.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone is an anti-inflammatory medication used to treat peripheral facial nerve palsy (Bell palsy). This patient's presentation suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Tissue plasminogen activator is used for acute ischemic stroke with motor weakness. However, thrombolytic therapy is not indicated for isolated facial nerve involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography evaluates for large vessel occlusion in acute stroke. This patient's time course and clinical findings do not suggest a large vessel stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurosurgical consultation is not indicated for isolated central facial palsy without evidence of a mass effect. This patient requires neurological evaluation and imaging to determine the underlying cause before considering surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with diabetes presents with a 24-hour history of right-sided facial weakness that began gradually upon awakening. She reports difficulty closing her right eye and drooping of the right side of her mouth. On examination, she cannot raise her right eyebrow or close her right eye completely, and she has flattening of the right nasolabial fold. Her speech is slightly slurred. The remainder of her neurological examination, including strength, sensation, and coordination, is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prednisone and artificial tears with nighttime eye protection
Acyclovir and supportive care
Electromyography and nerve conduction studies
Immediate neurosurgical consultation for surgical decompression
CT angiography of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has peripheral facial nerve palsy (Bell palsy) evidenced by an inability to raise the eyebrow and incomplete eye closure. Early initiation of oral corticosteroids within 48–72 hours improves recovery outcomes. Eye protection with artificial tears and nighttime taping or patching is essential to prevent exposure keratopathy and corneal ulcers due to lagophthalmos. This patient's diabetes does not contraindicate steroid therapy for this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

While antivirals may be considered as adjunctive therapy in Bell palsy, antivirals alone do not provide the anti-inflammatory benefits needed for facial nerve recovery.

C) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies are not part of the initial management for Bell palsy. These studies are typically reserved for patients with no improvement after 2–3 weeks or those with suspected polyneuropathy. Initial treatment should not be delayed for diagnostic testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate neurosurgical consultation is not indicated for typical Bell palsy. Surgical decompression is not routinely recommended due to significant risks and unclear benefits. The procedure is only considered for patients with severe illness and complete paralysis confirmed by nerve conduction studies.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is used to evaluate for stroke. This patient’s presentation with isolated peripheral facial nerve palsy and no other neurological deficits makes stroke unlikely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 12-hour history of left-sided facial weakness. She reports waking up this morning unable to smile properly and notes that her coffee tasted strange. She also has mild pain behind her left ear. Her medical history is unremarkable. On examination, she has a flattened left nasolabial fold and drooping of the left corner of her mouth. She is unable to wrinkle her forehead or fully close her left eye. The remainder of her neurologic examination, including limb strength and sensation, is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Initiate a course of oral prednisone
Obtain a non-contrast CT scan of the head
Provide lubricating eye drops and an eye patch only
Refer for urgent surgical decompression

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The key finding of Bell palsy is unilateral weakness of the entire side of the face, including the forehead, which distinguishes it from a central lesion such as a stroke. The mainstay of treatment is a course of oral corticosteroids, such as prednisone, initiated within 72 hours of symptom onset. The presumed pathophysiology involves inflammation and edema of the facial nerve within the facial canal. Corticosteroids reduce this inflammation, which can decrease the duration of symptoms and increase the likelihood of complete recovery. Adjunctive antiviral therapy may be considered for severe cases, but corticosteroids are the primary intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT of the head is used to evaluate for central causes of facial weakness, such as a stroke. However, this patient's inability to wrinkle her forehead indicates a peripheral nerve lesion. In the absence of other neurologic deficits or atypical features, the diagnosis of Bell palsy is made clinically, and routine imaging is not recommended as an initial step.

C) INCORRECT:

Eye care is a critical component of managing Bell palsy because of the inability to close the eye (lagophthalmos), which risks corneal abrasion and ulceration. Although lubricating drops and patching are essential supportive measures, they do not treat the underlying nerve inflammation or promote recovery of facial nerve function. Therefore, this represents incomplete management.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression of the facial nerve is an invasive procedure that may be considered in rare cases of severe, refractory Bell palsy with evidence of nerve degeneration on electrodiagnostic testing. It is not an initial management step and carries significant risks, including hearing loss and further nerve damage. Its overall efficacy remains controversial.
questions.hint: This patient's weakness of both the upper and lower face suggests Bell palsy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 24-hour history of left-sided facial weakness. She first noticed it this morning while trying to drink her coffee. She reports mild pain behind her left ear that started yesterday. She denies any limb weakness, sensory changes, or difficulty with speech or swallowing. She had a mild upper respiratory infection last week. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), and blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an inability to wrinkle the left side of her forehead, incomplete closure of the left eye, and drooping of the left corner of the mouth. The remainder of her neurologic examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe a course of oral acyclovir
Order an urgent non-contrast CT scan of the head
Perform electromyography of the facial muscles
Provide reassurance and recommend artificial tears
Initiate a course of oral prednisone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy, such as acyclovir or valacyclovir, is sometimes considered for severe cases of Bell palsy, based on the theory of herpes simplex virus reactivation as a potential cause. However, evidence shows little to no benefit from antivirals as monotherapy. Antivirals alone are not the most appropriate initial step.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroimaging is considered for facial weakness when a central cause, such as a stroke or tumor, is suspected. However, this patient's symptoms, specifically the involvement of the forehead muscles, and the absence of other focal neurologic deficits make a central lesion highly unlikely. For a classic presentation of Bell palsy, imaging is not indicated as part of the initial workup.

C) INCORRECT:

Electromyography and nerve conduction studies can be used to assess the severity of nerve damage and provide prognostic information in facial palsy. However, these tests are not useful in the acute setting and are typically reserved for patients with complete paralysis or those who show no signs of recovery after several weeks. They are not part of the initial management.

D) INCORRECT:

While reassurance and eye care (e.g., artificial tears, taping the eye closed at night) are crucial components of managing Bell palsy to prevent corneal injury, this option omits the primary medical intervention. Providing only supportive care is insufficient as the initial step in management.

E) CORRECT:

The most appropriate initial management for Bell palsy is a course of oral corticosteroids, such as prednisone, ideally started within 72 hours of symptom onset. The proposed mechanism is inflammation and edema of the facial nerve within the facial canal, and corticosteroids reduce this inflammation, improving the likelihood of complete recovery. In addition to pharmacotherapy, protective eye care with lubricating drops and patching is essential to prevent corneal abrasion due to incomplete eye closure (lagophthalmos).
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is typical of Bell palsy, an idiopathic, unilateral peripheral facial nerve palsy. The involvement of the entire hemiface, including the forehead, distinguishes it from a central lesion such as a stroke.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. He has a history of hypertension. Physical examination shows a flattened right nasolabial fold and drooping at the corner of his mouth. He has 4/5 strength in his right upper and lower extremities. Further neurologic evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Hyperacusis in the right ear
Decreased tear production in the right eye
Inability to close the right eyelid completely
Loss of taste on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Symmetrical wrinkling of the forehead

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperacusis, or increased sensitivity to sound, can result from paralysis of the stapedius muscle, which is innervated by a branch of the facial nerve. This is a classic sign of a peripheral, lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve. This finding is not a feature of a central, upper motor neuron lesion affecting the motor cortex.

B) INCORRECT:

The facial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers that control lacrimation via the greater petrosal nerve. Impaired tear production is a sign of a peripheral, lower motor neuron lesion affecting the facial nerve proximal to the geniculate ganglion. This finding is not expected with a central, upper motor neuron lesion, such as a stroke.

C) INCORRECT:

Inability to close the eyelid is due to weakness of the orbicularis oculi muscle. This finding, along with weakness of the entire ipsilateral side of the face, is characteristic of a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve, such as in Bell palsy. This patient's presentation with hemiparesis indicates a central, upper motor neuron cause, in which upper facial muscle function is preserved.

D) INCORRECT:

The chorda tympani, a branch of the facial nerve, provides taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Disruption of this function is a feature of a peripheral, lower motor neuron lesion affecting the facial nerve after it exits the brainstem. A central, upper motor neuron lesion, such as a stroke, would not typically cause this finding.

E) CORRECT:

The motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) receives input from the motor cortex. The portion of the nucleus that controls the lower face receives only contralateral cortical input. However, the portion that controls the upper face (e.g., frontalis muscle for wrinkling the forehead) receives bilateral cortical input. Therefore, a unilateral UMN lesion results in contralateral lower facial paralysis but spares the upper face, leading to symmetrical forehead wrinkling. This is a key feature distinguishing a central from a peripheral facial nerve palsy.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of acute hemiparesis with lower facial weakness raises suspicion for an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, such as an ischemic stroke.
